data.title: First time spending money on a gaming keyboard.
data.body:
I always just used my K120 Logitech Keyboard, its 10 bucks, I can use up to like 5 keys at once and never had trouble with how many keys Im allowed, its quiet when typing, the keys are easy to press and find, and it did the job well.

However, after 5 years of use, it broke. (Finally, I know right?) and I decided to spend a whole 7 dollars more on a keyboard.

Then I bought this, its terrible, the buttons are clickey, the cord is flimsey, the lights are so shiny it hurts my eyes.

Just kidding.

The buttons are amazing, what become easy to click, became easier, everything feels so smooth, the keys are fairly quiet but its probably just because I am a light typer. The lights allow me to turn my lights off and not have to guess where my keys are when I type. I found my WPM went up by 10 words per minute, originally it was 60, now its 70. Much easier to type because of the smooth and easy transition for my fingers and how open, easy, and strong the buttons are. Each button feels distinct and easy to find for my muscle memory.

The buttons are tough as nails, I can easily tell this keyboard will last a while, its easy to clean under them due to how the keyboard was made, literally can just blow the gunk off with a can of ultra duster.

As for the gaming part, every single key I press reacts, I can press as many damned keys as I want and they all work perfectly. The best part is how the F1 - F4 is set up, each F keys are lined in 4, this means in games that require me to use F1 - F4 are much easier to play because of how the intelligent designers set this up. For instance, in SC2 I need to press the F keys to set up my camera hotkey so its easier to move from location to location, I am CONSTANTLY pressing these keys as Zerg and before I always tended to hit ESC or F5 but because of how these keys are set up, I never make those mistakes again. And due to the distinction of the F keys, I never accidently hit the wrong F key anymore either. Dramatically improving my capability to play.

Whats more, sometimes even with my K120, I have to press more than 5 keys and that 6th key wont go through. This means if I have to run and turn, which is A, D, Shift, and then jump, space, and then press Capslock to talk, and then ult which is `, my ult wont go off because thats 6 keys. In Overwatch this is incredibly common. You need to constantly run, jump, talk, and sometimes ult at the same time. Many times I make this mistake, I will wind up dying or causing someone else to die. However, no longer does this happen with this keyboard!

The LED keys are great, not too bright. I wish I could have a only blue option but I dont mind.

I only have one negative thing to say: The space sucks balls, its loud, and... well its just loud. I am a very quiet typer because of how my fingers have to move quickly accross the keyboard and every time I have to press space I cringe a little. I found out why its like this, the springs arent tightened, whoever made this keyboard made the springs on it very loose however thats also another great thing about this keyboard: You can fix it because you can see the springs, which means with a knife or tweezers, you can easily push the springs apart a bit to tighten up the spacebar. I just havent gotten around to it.

This keyboard is a work of art, for the price, I'd say its 100 percent worth it. I'd say this is worth 60 bucks in my opinion but I'll go with 19, I aint complainin.

data.title: I'm insane for this membrane
data.body: Great and solid keyboard, fun times. Logitech and Razer must recognize the NPET! This keyboard is thin, not bulky, and has a solid METAL baseplate. It feels sturdy and heavy, doesn't slide around on my desktop. There are dual springs on the space bar and the keyboard includes a red key puller tool. The keystrokes are deep, precise and quiet. My typing/keystroke accuracy is much improved on this keyboard. No drivers were needed, and you can adjust the colors and effects just how you like them using the Function key on the keyboard. There is a Windows key lockout. The keyboard backlight turns off after a few idle minutes, and I am not sure if the time-out can be adjusted. The media keys work. Very solid keyboard for the price.

data.title: Solid budget level setup
data.body:
Was looking for a cheap and easy setup for a secondary PC that children would be using for general web browsing, homework, and occasional gaming. This combo fit the bill and then some. The feel of the keyboard is smooth and responsive with functional feedback and resistance in the keys. The only downside is the audible noise you get from keystrokes.
The Mouse is pleasantly smooth with good button engagement and response. The DPI switch is a very nice addition and performs flawlessly when needed.
The winning tick for this combo is the RGB quality at this price point. The keyboard provides an impressive array of colors that are not overly bright or distracting, but not so muted that they regress out of sight. The Mouse has a nice fading array of simplistic lines that adds to the ambiance of the lighting package.
Overall, I think it's a great package for light general use. The RGB features really add to the value and provide an impressive overall package for the price.

data.title: Well built sturdy keyboard, but mouse has some minor flaws.
data.body:
The keyboard is well built and has a nice weighty feel to it. The keys are very tactile, have a nice amount of travel, and make just enough sound to give positive audio confirmation when not looking directly at the keyboard.

The mouse on the other hand does have a few minor flaws.

First let me start off by saying that the mouse is the perfect size and weight. My last wireless mouse was smaller and got lost in my hand, and my hand is medium length.

This mouse has a long contoured profile and very responsive left right clicking buttons. The scroll wheel works fine but feels just a tab sluggish when scrolling.

My first issue is with the forward and back buttons located on the left side of the mouse. They are so delicately activated that with the absolute slightest of touch, I constantly found myself accidentally backing out of webpages, or forum posts completely losing all that I had typed. It become such an issue that I permanently removed the buttons (see photo).

My second issue is with the sides of the mouse being so slick that the mouse was darn near impossible to hold onto if you picked it off the surface for any reason. I constantly found myself picking up the mouse, only for it to drop 2 inches back to the desktop.
I actually had to add a small strip of traction tape to either side of the mouse (see photo) to alleviate this nuisance.

Other than those couple of minor issues, this setup is very nicely made and easy to use. The mouse issues could very well be personal to me and your experience may differ.

data.title: Solid build. A real keeper.
data.body:
Pro:
Nice feel. The stroke is a bit long compared to my last keyboard but the feel is excellent. Just while writing this review I have gotten used to the longer stroke.
Heavy back plate. This puppy is not sliding around without me intending to move it.
I am not sure if a mechanical keyboard but it sure feels like it.
Very inexpensive for a mechanical keyboard.
This will probably be the easiest keyboard to clean since when you used to unplug them and take them into the shower with you a 2 or 3 decades ago. There is no tray the keys are sitting in to hold dust, bits of potato chip, cat hair (my cats like laying on keyboards for some reason), ... I do not see even a reason to remove the keycaps except to put on different ones for different languages.

Con:
Tabs for raising angle of the keyboard, like so many including expensive keyboards are cheap fragile plastic and will probably break within a few months.
No macro keys, programmable or otherwise. To be honest this might be unfair. A great many keyboards have abandoned using macro keys but they really help with a lot of programs including productivity software but gaming especially. I think programming them gives people fits. Oh well. Also this is a very inexpensive keyboard with a mechanical keyboard feel.

Other:
The lighting schemes are nice but I would personally prefer just a straight white lighting behind the keys. I am retired. I am a vampire as to my sleep wake cycle. I am up usually all night long and up only in the daytime if there is something I have to do. I however do not wish to waste electricity so I tend to keep the lights off. This means I cannot see my keyboard and with my aging eyes, I really want as much contrast to make it easy to read what the keys are at night.
I am considering purchasing another couple for backups for when this eventually (hopefully far in the future) fails.

data.title: Best for the price
data.body: Keys are a bit blocky, but best for the price. Works great, color is great.

data.title: Lights Out After 7 Minutes
data.body:
As strictly a keyboard? This product is...fairly good. Keys have a nice feel to them. No false key clicks, no excessive pressure required and so on. Would be nice if the letters were solid and didn't contain spaces in them like they were printed using an old stencil but, hey, so what if my "B" key looks like a palm tree growing out of the ground if viewed sideways? And my "O" key an omega symbol without the loops on the ends?

Where this product really fails is with the backlight timeout. If you don't press a key, it's "lights out" after 7 minutes and 11 seconds. No way to adjust that or turn it off. You've got to find...in the dark...because your backlit keyboard isn't lit...and press a key to turn it on again.

Oh, and I'll save you the effort of using a search engine for a hack or solution: There isn't one. Any ones that you find apply strictly to the cordless version. If you're using the USB version like I am, none of those work. Which is kind of silly because, seriously, how much power are you going save by turning off the backlight after 7 minutes of keyboard inactivity...pennies?

So, if you want a continuously lit keyboard, this isn't the one for you. If you want keys without strange gaps in the lettering, this isn't the one for you. Other than that? Go for it.

data.title: Color lit keyboard at affordable price
data.body:
Small enough to fit on a desk.
The keys are distinct and easy to use for accurate typing.
Love the colors!

data.title: Nice keyboard, HERE'S HOW TO DO THE COLOR CHANGES!
data.body:
The keyboard shipping in 2024 has NO "LED" Key as spoken of in other comments! The manual lists the MODEL NUMBERS and instructions for EACH, so check your model number listed on the underside!

How to CHANGE COLORS, stop ROTATION, and change brightness on model K10V3 or K10V4:

To change BRIGHTNESS: Fn + ↑ or Fn + ↓ There are 4 LEVELS from NONE to fully BRIGHT
To change to SOLID COLOR: Fn + Home (you'll get solid RED), then repeat that to cycle 8 color options, from 7 solid colors, to the rainbow spread, NONE OF THEM FLASHING!

So far, happy with the keyboard, not completely silent, but not bothersome at all. And the keystrokes seem consistently smooth to use with none sticking. In daylight, I also think the brightness of the solid colors is very good when turned full up. Would buy again.

data.title: For a budget price a good keyboard that both a general purpose or office and gamers should like.
data.body:
NPET K10 Backlit Gaming Keyboard, Black, Purchased 10/22, Reviewed 10/22/2022
I purchased the K10 budget membrane faux mechanical keyboard. I was searching for a backup budget keyboard because my main PC keyboard gave up the ghost after 7 years. I needed a backup so I could continue working from home, while I waited for the new replacement keyboard to arrive next week.

1st impression: when I grabbed the Amazon package at my front door, I thought, "Wow, this is a heavy keyboard." Opening the package, I was impressed with its mechanical keyboard look, and it looked like a quality keyboard but at a budget price of $20. Of course, as soon as I set the K10 on the desk, I started testing the keypress feedback, noise, and how typing felt. Key travel felt a tiny bit stiff but still good for this price point. Any keying noise was surprisingly low.

Plugging in the K10's braided USB cable, the first con is revealed: the cable is too short at 67" long, another 6 to 12 inches would be better. The board's RGB lights lit up, and my Windows 10 Pro PC had no issues with the new K10. The next thing I noticed, which is not necessarily a negative, is that the keys are smaller than typical full-sized keyboard keys.  [Update "edit" 4/12/23: I later compared my full size keyboard and the new replacement keyboard I had ordered, and the keypad surface area is the same. (What was different was the K10's top surface has a slightly deeper concave indentation, so the feel is slightly different.)] I am a touch typist capable of 60+wpm so the size of the keypad felt a little off; however, with use, it would feel fine. With nearly 40 years of using and owning many computers and their keyboards, touch typing resulted in some initial missed direct keypad hits, but adjusting was easy. One additional observation: right after startup, a distinct odor was coming from the board, sort of an electrical and plastic overheating smell (note, I had the RGB lights off). After about 20 minutes, it faded, and I haven't noticed it since.  [edit 4/12/23 I have been using nearly 5 months most days on my Hosting Music pc and no issues at all.]

What does a touch typist think of the key typing on the K10?
• Sore fingers. My fingers were tired after 1 hour, and after 2 hours, they were sore. The problem is how I type, pushing down slightly harder than the average typist, who maybe learned to type on a mushy membrane keyboard. I learned on IBM Selectrics, which required a slightly heavier key press. The keystroke travel is higher or longer on the floating keys of the K10 than on most keyboards at 3.6mm, so I have to push further down for it to bottom out the key travel, and if I am typing hard and fast, my fingers are sore. I tested where the action point in the key travel seemed to be; it's either halfway or slightly higher. So if I type with a lighter keystroke and try to avoid the key bottoming out, there should be less soreness. A lighter touch is possible, and the keys feel good as you type along and shouldn't cause sore fingers. I would like the stroke to be a little softer or less stiff. [edit 4/12/23   After some practice, I haven't had any soreness issues.]
• "Noise," a comment about YouTube reviewers Any YT review doing their keyboard review on a wooden desk or a hard desk surface with no large mouse pad that cushions and accommodates both the keyboard and mouse is only testing the keyboard's resonance with the hard desk, and that is likely 2x or 3x louder than typing with a keyboard on a desk size keyboard - mouse pad. Typing noise on the K10 sitting on a 32" x 12" x 2-3mm thick pad was very low.
•No movement, the K10 on my full-size keyboard/mouse pad does not slide or move at all. The K10's weight and three rubber grip pads on the front bottom of the chassis, plus the two pull-out feet, securely hold the board with no movement.
• Key wobble was not noticeable, very slight on the space bar.
• RGB lights, are not my thing, but if there was an RGB selection that lit only the key letters and numbers, that would be ideal. However, it's not an option.

I have about 27 days to decide if I should keep the K10 or return it to Amazon. I'm pretty sure it's a keeper.

[Update: 4/12/23, I kept the K10 and use it almost daily. For the price and for my type of usage, I would recommend the K10. Would it be a good gaming keyboard? I do play games, I tried it for one game, and it was fine, I have never owned an expensive gaming board or typed on one, so I cannot compare. ]

data.title: Not Perfect but i like it
data.body: I like how it feels while clicking, its quick to respond to my inputs. Although i like the colors they may b a little to bright and i tend to turn them off to use it since having them in the corner of my eyes is a little annoying and they always come back on when you turn it on and off again so you will have to keep doing it.

data.title: Third time is a charm
data.body: This is an awesome keyboard, especially for the money. It has a metal base, so it is solid and doesn't move easily. It has two little supports on the back to angle it towards you, which is nice. Also, I love the light function. It is easy to toggle between the different light functions. This is actually the third keyboard that I got because with the other two, one was too small/compressed and one had a return key on the right that was in a different formation, so I would keep hitting the slash key. All things considered 10/10.

data.title: Love it!
data.body: Who wouldn’t like all the bright colors moving across and adding color to my workspace! Love that it goes to sleep after no use for a few minutes so I can leave and not have the keyboard just keep going. Has great functionality and the little instructions show you how to change and use the keyboard fully. Worth it and then some! So impressed

data.title: Very good gaming keyboard
data.body: I receive the product, it's really good. Clicks are silent. Typing in this thing is really comfortable. I got the wired version of this keyboard and it perfroms well. Lots of LED colors you can set on the keyboard. Just one problem is that some buttons are hard to click but if you don't have no problem with that then It's a must-buy for a cheap keyboard.

data.title: Cool looking Zelda key :)
data.body: Over all i really like this keyboard. The colors are nice but are also able to turn off which is good. Keys are quiet but deep like i like them. Only thing i would change is the length of the charging cord. i'd prefer to keep it plugged in at all times so i don't have to worry about it dying on me but its just a tad too short to reach from the back of my computer tower, through my desk to the keyboard. Otherwise, I love the feel & look.

data.title: Good quality and good for gaming!
data.body: I usually dont write reviews but after using this keyboard and looking for an 'upgraded gaming keyboard' I had to come back and write one. Compared to some Logitec and Razer keyboards this one is a much better choice especially given the price is 1/3. It was so good I decided to get a 2nd but in the wireless version. The keys havent worn down, sas in there is no noticable fading of the letters and I have used it a LOT for gaming. The AWSD keys have no sign of wear. Thumbs up for this keyboard!

data.title: Excellent Keyboard at a Great Price!
data.body: I have purchased two of these keyboards. I enjoyed the first one so much I purchased one to replace the keyboards I get at the office. The games have a good mechanical feel with tactile and audible feedback, and no annoying noise (springs popping, "clackiness"). The keyboard sits flat, no rocking. And the backlight works well, though I stick with a uniform green you can make it do any color plus motion. I may purchase another just to have a spare or to use with my laptop on the road.

data.title: Key logos not very legible
data.body: I thought this was a pretty cool keyboard with illumination from underneath. And I thought that that illumination would make the markings on the keys stand out pretty well. But in actuality, it is harder to read than a regular keyboard with black faces and white letters. I’m keeping it anyway because it seems to work very nicely with the robust tall keys.

data.title: Great for price
data.body: Love that this keyboard goes to sleep when when not in use.

data.title: For the price can't complain
data.body:
It feels durable but also kind of cheap but it works well and can use in the dark no issue. Soft press are decent, dongle works well. Charging cable is nice length

Downside is top media button do not light up and led color Pattern resets when shut off/on

data.title: NPET K10 Keyboard is Almost perfect for me
data.body: I like to wait a while before writing a review. I purchased the NPET Oct 2020, and have not had any issues with the performance at all. I like the three different lighting choices. The board turns off when the PC sleeps, but if there is a program still running on the PC the keyyboard will continue to stay lit. The keys are very nice, noisy and very well spaced for what the work is needed for. Luckily, I know where to place my fingers on a QWERTY keyboard as the ink on the letters began rubbing off less than a year. I attempted to look for replacements and the replacements were just a few dollars less than the device itself. Unfortunately, I am the only person able to use the keyboard if I have guests who do not know letter keyboarding well.

data.title: Love me some raised keys!
data.body: This keyboard and wrist pad is awesome. The added bonus is the lights under the keys.

data.title: Fun gaming keyboard
data.body: This has been a welcome addition to our game room. Lots of color and works great!

data.title: Good and cheap
data.body: Worked for a temp fix

data.title: Great Keyboard
data.body: The keys have good key travel and sound amazing. Love the LED lights as well and the keyboard feels sturdy. Battery life is amazing and I haven’t charged it since opening it. Overall great keyboard for the price.

data.title: This thing never failed me.
data.body: This keyboard works amazing and I bought it years ago. The most that might go wrong would be 4 magnets on the back slipping off because the glue wore down but you can just gorilla glue it to the keyboard and problem solved. Also there are 3 color settings as well as a complete off setting if you don't like all the colors.

data.title: Great Keyboard!
data.body: The design and execution of this product is outstanding. It is beautiful and my kids loves the keyboard! The foam feels like heaven when I have my wrist resting on it.

data.title: Easy to use
data.body: I am impressed with the light-up color. No more batteries. This keyboard has a long-lasting charge.

data.title: As nice as any I've ever owned
data.body: Have never owned super premium but have owned nice keyboards. This is on par or better than those.

data.title: Great for the price
data.body: Looks good and works as intended.

data.title: UPDATE: Nice mouse and keyboard but...
data.body:
UPDATE: I received great customer service. I was having issues with my keyboard and mouse holding charge and customer service sent me a new one.

Nice mice and keyboard. However, they both stopped holding charge after about 2 months of use. I contacted customer support and will update review accordingly...

data.title: Overall pretty good
data.body: Over all keyboard and led lights are pretty good. Some of the letters looks like it wasn't cut out completely so it looks like the whole letter is not completely visible. Other thank that not bad.

data.title: Works
data.body: Nice for the price

data.title: Perfect
data.body: I love this keyboard! It works well and it stays charged for quite a while. The mouse is a good size and also lasts a while. I like that they light up. The price was great and definitely worth it. It’s very easy to use, just plug and play.

data.title: Not working right out the box. For the second time...
data.body:
Second time I ordered this item. Both times keyboard dead right out of the box. Won't take a charge and lights won't turn on. Big waste of time. Now I have to fiddle with another return for the second time. Very disappointing. I strongly encourage you look elsewhere for a keyboard and mouse...

UPDATE: Company reached out to me and made sure I got one that worked. Thanks 😊

I have to say this item feels pretty high quality. And I really like the way the keys feel. Back lighting is nice and bright. I'm really hope this unit lasts...

data.title: Lovley!
data.body: The product is what it says it is. Light's up like the mouse, is colorful and better than my old keyboard. I highly recommend this product.

data.title: Just what I needed ...
data.body: Useful and has a good "key feel".

data.title: Edit: I like this keyboard but could be better.
data.body:
Pros:
* Priced well (I paid $29.99. At the time of writing this review it is 25.99)
* Feels great to type on.
* RGB options are decent but can be turned off as well
* USB A to USB C cable included
* Rechargeable built in battery

Cons:
* There's better RGB options out there if RGB is your thing but not at this price range
* EDIT: Connecting the keyboard to a computer via the USBC cable doesn't allow you to type. Only charge

I've been using this keyboard for about a month now and I have to say I was very surprised at how much I actually like this. I was looking for a wireless keyboard that didn't include a mouse since I already have so many mouse and I didn't want another one. I came across this keyboard and it appeared to be the best for the price. I really like the way it feels when you type. There's a good amount of feedback but it doesn't have that super "clicky" sound that Cherry MX Blue keyboards do. Though there is a softer tactile sound which I like.

In terms of RGB, there's a few presets on the keyboard but there's no software to customize them. You can choose different led presets by pressing the LED button on top of the "Home" button (see pics). Also try pressing "FN" + "LED" buttons and the keyboard will add a cool breathing theme to the lights. You can turn the brightness of the lights up or down by pressing "FN"+"Pg Up"/"Pg Dn". There's only three levels of brightness though. You have the option to turn off the RGB all together if that isn't your thing by pressing the "LED" button a few times which is what I usually do. If you really like RGB there's other keyboards out there that are better if you are willing to pay more.

I also really like the fact that the battery is rechargeable via any USBC cable. They provide a USB A to USBC cable in the box which you can use to connect to a charger. The charge from what I can tell lasts a long time. I've never had to charge it after a month.

They missed a great opportunity here where they could have made the keyboard work both wired and wireless but they only made it work wirelessly. I think this was a missed opportunity because it would have been beneficial to gamers who care about response times and also the reason why I'm taking off a star.

Also to linux users that are wondering, this did work for me wirelessly on Pop OS without having to do any kind of driver installations so it should work fine for any Ubuntu based distros. I can't confirm for other distros but I would think it should work fine.

All in all this is a very good keyboard. I would recommend it to professionals trying to get their work done. I wouldn't recommend it to gamers who play competitive games.

data.title: It is great!
data.body: The large buttons are great. It lights up too.

data.title: Pretty decent keyboard
data.body: I love the floating keys and the light show the keyboard supplies. I don’t use it for gaming so I cannot speak to that aspect. For quality though, it serves the purpose well. The only significant drawback is that you can’t see the letters light up very well from the backlight unless you’re standing up. I’ve had other keyboards that are far superior in that regard. Overall though, it’s a decent keyboard.

data.title: Just get it!! its amazing
data.body: my boyfriend absolutely loves this keyboard. Its big, comfortable, led, and has so many extra keys and features. 10/10 keyboard it does more than its job.

data.title: Good keyboard
data.body: Good all around keyboard.

data.title: LOVING THIS KEYBOARD
data.body: THE BOARD IS VERY COMFORTABLE. THE LIGHTED BACKGROUND IS VIVID AND A GREAT PERK!

data.title: KEYS ARE PERFECT TO USE. I NEED BIGGER KEYS
data.body: THIS IS AN AWESOME KEYBOARD AND PRICE WAS VERY REASONABLE. EVERYONE LOVES THE COLOR CHANGES.

data.title: Love it
data.body: I bought this for work, it’s been great and easy to use haven’t had any problems, recommend it to my coworker they bought one too!

data.title: Perfect for gamers
data.body: It’s kinda small but has all the right features and colors just right for gamers. Item is as described by the seller! Would recommend!

data.title: Good for gaming
data.body: Affordable keyboard for everyday use and gaming.

data.title: Just what I was looking for.
data.body: I really like this keyboard, plenty of backlighting color options, inexpensive, works great, looks cool & NO software installation or updates required, just plug it in and use it. I highly recommend this keyboard.

data.title: works well
data.body: nice item but found others just as good at half the price on temu!

data.title: Nice keyboard for a nice price!
data.body: I like the feel and spacing of this keyboard. I have larger hands and it feels natural for me. The keys are responsive. The backlit sadly only has 3 settings: (green, blue, red), (blue, red, green), or (cyan, magenta, yellow) each in 1/3 of the keyboard. There is a flashing mode too.

data.title: Durable and well made.
data.body: I needed to replace a current keyboard and didn't want to pay alot for a keyboard at the time. Worth it 100% Price was way more than reasonable. I didn't want to leave a premature review. 3 months since I bought it. I am pleased with this product. I would recommend it to friends.

data.title: Works well, not crazy about the lighting colors
data.body: Works well, but I don't really like the colors of the lighting of the keyboard. Has a pretty good battery life and good response to the keys and mouse.

data.title: Good
data.body: Space bar broke kinda easily but it was also easy to fix and it hasn't gave me anymore problems

data.title: Not bad
data.body: Decent keyboard. Works better than a lot of the more expensive brands. Some of the keys are a little hard to read. Figuring out the lighting isn’t the easiest but not impossible.

data.title: Mouse hibernates quickly.
data.body: Keyboard is NOT lightweight. Had a metal frame on the underside. Mouse hibernates after a few minutes of inactivity causing you to click the button to wake it up. Not bad, but I have accidentally clicked on things I didn't mean to just whole waking up my mouse. Great for gaming. NOT great for working from home.

data.title: Good product
data.body: I like these keyboards, but had some fading on some keys, but no complaints. Would buy from again.

data.title: Well Loved, but Only Lasted a Year
data.body:
Purchased this keyboard a little over a year ago (October 2022), and I truly love it! I am not a gamer, or anything fancy like that. I use the keyboard for my workstation (I WFH).

I am a fairly quick typer, and for whatever reason, last week, the keyboard started skipping letters as I was typing. It wasn't the same letter (I checked), and it wasn't consistent. So, I made sure to charge it over the weekend, and sure enough, Monday morning...still skipping random letters as I was typing. Haven't made any changes to the way I was hitting the keys. I am going to say that after 13 months of using it (on average) 6 days a week, for 9 hours (avg) a day, the keyboard is dying on me.

I get on Amazon to look at purchasing another keyboard, and sure enough, I am a sucker!

I truly love this keyboard (see image of well-loved keys).

I appreciate having the backlight (I get migraines, so sometimes my overhead light is off). I am a big fan of the auditory feedback mechanical keyboards give me, and the "clacking" is JUST. RIGHT on this one.

I don't have to worry about battery replacements (thank goodness), just charge it once or twice a week at this point, and I am good to go!

But how can I make it last longer than a year?? Sigh

data.title: Awesome keyboard!
data.body: I really like this keyboard.

data.title: Love the keyboard. Some improvements over old charge port , now c is better.
data.body: I have bought like everyone else at least a dozen wireless keyboards and the charge port always breaks. This is better with the C style. Hopefully I can make it last.

data.title: Keith
data.body: This gaming keyboard is a great addition to my pc. The illumination is amazing. The keys are easy to push and feel sturdy.

data.title: Decent but 0 key sticks on 10 key
data.body: comfortable keyboard and like that it's quite, however on the 10 key area the 0 key sticks sometimes and have to press hard to make it work.

data.title: The letters are rubbing off
data.body: I really like it and think it works well. Unfortunately the letters are rubbing/ chipping away. I’m pretty good at typing but it gets harder the more keys that are blank.

data.title: Flashing lights are a distraction.
data.body: A lot to like about this keyboard. Google key touch and sturdy construction. The lights could be one of them but they power up in a swirling rainbow which is distracting and some colors do not illuminate the keys well. (I work in a dark environment. ) instructions say this can be controlled with the "[LED]" key but nothing on the keyboard says or suggests "LED" to me. Sent an inquiry to the dealer/manufacturer a week ago but they have not responded.

data.title: Amazing For Sensory Needs!
data.body: I wanted a deep key, LED keyboard, and I got one! Charges fast, sounds amazing, and has multi color schemes. If you're a sensory seeking buyer, this is the keyboard for you at an affordable price!

data.title: Feels good and smooth
data.body: Nice built, strong Keyes very quiet. Feels rugged and tuff. Used it for 3 weeks home office, still going strong.

data.title: Right half LEDs dont work after a few weeks
data.body: Works fine as a keyboard but the LEDs on the right half wont light up anymore, I got this a few weeks ago :(

data.title: Awesome Keyboard For Gaming On The Go!
data.body: I love this keyboard and mouse combo! Super affordable and very portable! The USB to wirelessly connect to the computer is small and different from other wireless setups. I travel for work and can't stand the keyboard on my laptop, so this was a must. The keyboard has a nice click on it and is comfortable to use, it feels anything, but cheap and the mouse is very compact, but not too small! I love gaming and everyday browsing with this setup!

data.title: Two things:
data.body: This is an absolutely tremendous keyboard for the price, especially if you need the sensory aspect of typing. Two things: the first time I ordered it, one key was broken, and I had to send it back for a replacement. Not sure if anyone else had this issue, but it may be indicative of broader quality control issues. The second thing is that turning off the keyboard disco required me to look here, in the reviews, as the method for turning off the lights (or changing them) was *NOT* what the instruction manual said. Please see one of the other reviews for instructions--you can change it.

data.title: Lighted, quiet keyboard
data.body: I needed a new keyboard and realized that a backlight would benefit me. Sometimes I turn on my computer in low light and need to see the keys. I like that the backlighting "times out" after a few minutes when you are not using it, and all it takes is one touch to turn it back on. This keyboard is higher (thicker) than my old keyboard, so I pulled out my gel keyboard wrist rest and it was perfect. I recommend the wrist rest with this keyboard. I was able to understand the instructions for the keyboard, so I can turn adjust the lighting with the correct function. It uses a USB to plug into my computer and worked right away. I like the bounce on the keyboard and am pleased with how quiet it is. It was a good value, too!!

data.title: I like it
data.body: I like this

data.title: Functional
data.body: I have yet to use it for gaming but so far so good. Haven't had a mechanical keyboard in some time. Didn't expect it to come with a key cap remover.

data.title: Works as advertised.
data.body: If you don't mind the 6 to 8 hour run time before needing to be recharged it is worth the price. I think if the unit came with 2 pop out batteries so one could be charging while the other is in use it would be perfect :)

data.title: Easy to set up
data.body: Easy to setup nice not to worry about battires just charge it up when needed.

data.title: It's fine.
data.body:
I've not had any major issues with it.

I've had the keyboard for 16 months. I'm an enterprise software developer - so while i use the keyboard every day, i'm not straight up typing all day long.

The key caps are cheap and mine have started to deteriorate. This is not an issue of functionality, though - the black paint is wearing off, exposing the translucent material of the caps such that more light is let through, and you can no longer read the letter. The space bar now has a huge blob that lets light through.

Recently i've seen an issue where Windows seems to think the Windows key is constantly pressed, and i have never encountered this using any other keyboard. Even with the ability on this keyboard to lock out the Win key, it continues to happen. I've turned off sticky keys and all of the related nonsense in Windows, but the issue randomly continues to happen. Unplugging the keyboard and plugging it back in doesn't correct the problem - only a full reset will fix it. It's certainly possible that this is not the fault of the keyboard, but as i've never once seen this in the past 30 years i've used windows, i thought i should mention it.

My only other gripe is that i find the colors a bit annoying. I wish there was just a regular white backlight option. For the first few months of use, i just had the lights off. But the key caps are very shiny, and although i'm certainly able to type without looking at the keyboard for 95% of the time, there are still a few symbols and F keys i need to look at. The shininess means that there's enough glare to make the keys unreadable.

So overall, it's fine. It's better than the $10 keyboards i've used most of my life. It's easy to clean, feels fine to type on all day, and hasn't completely disintegrated over the past year. Given the price, it's hard to argue with it.

data.title: Everything is good except for the down arrow key that broke after a week.
data.body:
The NPET K10 Gaming Keyboard is a membrane-style gaming keyboard that has been designed for gamers.

In terms of build quality, the keyboard appears to be well-made with a durable plastic construction and a comfortable design. However, the fact that the down arrow key broke just a week after use is a concerning issue and raises questions about the keyboard's overall durability.

In terms of performance, the keyboard has a range of gaming-specific features, such as anti-ghosting and media controls, that make it well-suited for gaming. The backlit keys are also a nice touch and allow for comfortable use in low light conditions. However, the broken down arrow key could be an inconvenience for some users and may affect their gaming experience.

The keyboard is also relatively affordable, making it a good option for gamers on a budget. However, the fact that a key broke just a week after use suggests that there may be issues with the keyboard's overall durability and quality.

Overall, the NPET K10 Gaming Keyboard appears to have some attractive features for gamers, but the broken down arrow key raises concerns about the keyboard's durability. As with any product, it's important to weigh the pros and cons before making a purchase, and to consider the potential risks and drawbacks before buying.

data.title: Very comfortable and snappy, but the lighting is all wrong.
data.body: Key feel is good, works well, but the one thing couldn't stand was that the light comes up around the bottom of the keys, and the letters on the keys themselves do not light up. Totally useless to me for what I needed it for as I wanted to be able to see the characters on the keys for use in darkened conditions. Never even used up the first charge on the batteries before I ordered a different brand that has light up characters.

data.title: Feels great
data.body: I game a lot, had alot of different boards. But this one feels great, the lightning it well done. Fn + Home or End changes the effect. Fn + arrow up or down changes brightness. Most keys have a great feel to them beside the spacebar. But only notice if you nit pick. It has a metal backing as well, which is great for longevity.

data.title: See attachment for information
data.body: This is a great keyboard and mouse so far. I will update if I find anything unusual. I do not game but I work 9 hours a day with a keyboard. I wanted to get a mechanical because I like the feel better. If you do not need the back light this keyboard and mouse last all week without charging. If you need the back light then it will last about 20 hours. I have attached a pic of some controls since it does not come with instructions. Happy Typing.

data.title: It's great for the price.
data.body: Obviously there are some down sides. The rgb is slightly darker in some places and it doesn't come with instructions to control the rgb but it's awesome for the price. Definitely worth it.

data.title: good for price, but beware
data.body:
1st, this is a good keyboard for the money, but beware:
- I liked my old NPET keyboard better(keys felt less spongy, personal preference).
- The clear letters/numbers on the keys that the LED light bleeds through are not high quality and crisp lettering (hard to make out what some symbols are).
- The LED color constantly scrolls across the keyboard. You can slow it down, but it still does it.
- The LEDs don't just shine through the keys. The light shines up under the keys too. This is distracting. I just want the light to be under the keys so I can make out what the keys are in a dark room and I want to be able to dim the LEDs down to the point where I can still make out the symbols/letters/numbers, but not blind me. Its similar to the effect of turning the light on in your vehicle at night.
- The LEDs have a sleep function which could be nice, but you need the ability to turn it off. I have to hit the ctrl button to wake it back up so that I can see the button that I actually need to press.

data.title: It just will not die
data.body: i am really liking this key board and it is very durable and it will not die.

data.title: Not quiet at all
data.body: Advertised as very quiet, but quite the opposite

data.title: Good keyboard
data.body: I’m not a gamer, but I like this style of keyboard for work. It took me a minute to figure out how to change the backlight from constantly changing color to solid color, but once I did it was great.

data.title: needed a cheap kb
data.body: 16 bucks black friday is a deal

data.title: LED Key is actually (M2 Home) key on this model. Love this keyboard
data.body:
Love this keyboard Bought one for myself and then purchased 2 more: one for my wife and another one as a spare backup or for the keys in case they wear out. ( can not find replacement keys on-line for this product . However for the price, it made sense to me just to buy a back-up.
___________________________________________________________________________________
Instructions are a bit sketchy. " What is referred to as LED key is actually the M2 (home ) key " on this model .. Hitting the Fn key and the M2 key together allows you to see the keyboard lighting colors that are available, )
Stopping on the color that you prefer sets that color as a default'

data.title: Wireless PC Keyboard
data.body:
I've had it a few days now and LOVE it! It's been years sense I last purchased my keyboard and spilled coffee : ( this caused my number keys to stick, yuk. This new keyboard is made to avoid such accidents from damaging the keys, I can only hope, lol.

It's much quieter than the old one, I actually kinda miss that tapping noise as I typed- hubby doesn't! Great product for the price and the back lite keys are nice. I'm not a gamer, so I can attest to that, ergonomic was really what was top on my list. I'm Very Happy! Highly recommend this keyboard.

data.title: Works well, but the paint on the keys is not great
data.body: Works well, and is nice and bright. But the paint on the letters of the keys is spotty. I suppose you get what you pay for.

data.title: Perfect Keyboard - Alot of light combinations and control
data.body:
Very nice lighterd keyboard

Change colors brightness etc.

Very nice quality materials

data.title: it works
data.body: I have moved on to mechanical but this works as a beginner keyboard

data.title: Works great, feels great
data.body:
Play Video
Feels great, looks great, works perfectly. Only down side, it is a little noisier then my last key board. Definitely worth the money

data.title: Decent keyboard
data.body: I only gave it 4 stars only because the RGB keeps shutting off after a couple of minutes. If this were a wireless keyboard that would be fine but for a wired keyboard that shouldn't even be an option and for me it's not acceptable. That being said everything else is perfect. Edit- I've tried every button combo I can think of to get the RGB to just stay on and I figure it out, and the instructions don't say anything about it.

data.title: It’s OK
data.body:
I bought this based on high customer satisfaction. However, there are two main items of concern. One, the keys don’t light up. There is a backlight, but the keys are not lit so if you’re in a dark room, you can’t see the keys if you need to see them. Second, and way worse, the Space bar squeaks EVERY time I hit it. And I type MASSIVE amounts for work and it drives me absolutely crazy. I try to drown it out with music but it doesn’t help (maybe if I use headphones). But that Space bar squeaking makes me want to smash this keyboard through the wall.

EDIT: I popped off the space bar, brushed off the area, pushed down on the springs a few times, put the space bar back on, and it doesn’t squeak anymore.

data.title: Ok I guess
data.body: I loved that color, that's about it. Didn't like the feel of the keys and HATED the font. It looked like some letters were already worn out. I returned it. I am rating it a 3 because it worked fine for the 5 min it was plugged in 🤭

data.title: Love the lights but difficult to see the letters.
data.body: I love the colorful glowing lights and the feel of the keys when typing. However, I had to purchase stickers and glue them on the keys because I couldn’t make out the letters/characters. The letters are too faint to see, especially in daylight/office light. They might be visible if you’re working in complete darkness, but I rarely do that.

data.title: Bright colors!
data.body: This keyboard loses USB connectivity fairly often. It's a matter of unplugging, then re-connecting to yhe USB port.

data.title: Just what I needed
data.body: Bought this to replace a non lit wireless keyboard I had for years. This one works great, you can leave it plugged in to charge and it still works. I like that it lights up to see the keys when I'm working at 5am.

data.title: Nice touch
data.body: I like the keys and how they type. The keys feel like piano keys. I don’t make typing errors since the keys are are not flat or close together

data.title: A major step up
data.body:
I'm not a gamer, but an engineer who has been using PC's since we booted from floppies.. Based on backlit keyboard and price I bought this unit, replacing a basic keyboard that came with the PC. The difference is amazing. The tactile feedback, the feel of the contoured keys, makes it a joy to use. I'm making far fewer fat finger errors.

As someone who eats too often at the keyboard the fact that the keyboard is "waterproof" and the way the keys are mounted and removable makes it much easier to keep the keyboard clean and functional.

The documentation that came in the box is minimal, but a quick search found very helpful online sites including a video on the features of the keyboard.

It is an amazing keyboard for the price.

data.title: Love this keyboard
data.body: I love this keyboard. Bought one for my office and my home office.
